pull.title: Eliminate the use of points and scalars from secp256k1_ecmult_strauss_batch.
pull.body:
We have secp256k1_ecmult_strauss_wnaf invoke the callback itself.

This builds upon PR #899.

repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

repo.name: secp256k1
repo.description: Optimized C library for EC operations on curve secp256k1

issue.title: Reduce stratch space needed by ecmult_strauss_wnaf.

events.body:
I only reviewed the last 2 commits, since the rest are from #899 .

I think the callback/adaptor is a nice idea for optimizing space usage, but my main concern is about possibly breaking the "public" API (see inline comment).

A quick check of `./bench_ecmult strauss_wnaf` at three different versions shows that there are no immediately obvious performance regressions:

![Plot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4276679/144323733-7b3a86eb-0044-4b51-bca5-bf0bba456abf.png)

events.message: Eliminate the prej array from ecmult_strauss_wnaf.
Eliminate the pre_a_lam array from ecmult_strauss_wnaf.
Eliminate na_1 and na_lam state fields from ecmult_strauss_wnaf.
Eliminate input_pos state field from ecmult_strauss_wnaf.

Eliminate the use of points and scalars from secp256k1_ecmult_strauss_batch.
We have secp256k1_ecmult_strauss_wnaf invoke the callback itself.
Remove the unused points and scalars allocation from secp256k1_ecmult_strauss_batch.

events.body: I'm going to close this PR.  I don't feel like pursing it; I'm not really convinced it is worthwhile.  If, for whatever reason, someone disagree and does think it is worthwhile, feel free to take it over.

perhaps document which global z everything is set to?

comments.body: It's probably because I don't know how to GitHub, but I intended for these comments to end up on #899 instead.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -82,7 +82,7 @@
  *  contain prej[0].z / a.z. The other zr[i] values = prej[i].z / prej[i-1].z.

comments.body:
If you're checking the return value of `secp256k1_ecmult_strauss_wnaf` when you call it here, would you also need to check it when you call it at the end of `secp256k1_ecmult`?

My concern is that if the callback (and thus the call to `secp256k1_ecmult_strauss_wnaf`) "fails", this could either (1) introduce a way for `secp256k1_ecmult` to fail unexpectedly, or (2) force `secp256k1_ecmult` to return `int` instead of `void`, and either way this would break the "public" API.
